doc.title: GS CONSUMER: Luxury Catalyst Path / India GST changes / Kering & Artemis / Armani / Nestle / Inditex / L'Oreal
doc.source_uri: 2025-09-02/GS CONSUMER_ Luxury Catalyst Path _ India GST changes _ Kering & Artemis _ Armani _ Nestle _ Inditex _ L'Oreal_2025-09-02

passages.text: GOLDMAN SACHS FICC AND EQUITIES Consumer - Specialist Sales
All references to "we/us/our" refer to the views and observations of the desk unless specified otherwise. Max loss limited to amount invested.

- The Luxury sector remains highly topical following our bullish push on 20 Aug and a competitor upgrading a couple of stocks in the space today.- Over the last week, we have seen both LO and HF buying of Luxury on the single stock desk (LVMH, Kering, Hermes, Moncler, Brunello) as fundamental investors looked to play 1) better US data; 2) Q3 consensus numbers which look intact. In addition, we've seen some decent buying of our basket (GSXELUXG) which, feedback suggests, is more about the China trade. Following the largest ever monthly net buying of China equities in our prime book (in notional terms, with a +3 sigma move vs the last 10 years), HF gross allocation to China is approaching 2 yr highs and macro funds are looking for a 2nd derivative China trade.- My view remains unchanged in terms of end-demand trends in this sector. I have good conviction that the US is tracking ahead of expectations for Q3, supported by broad-based data showing an improvement in discretionary spending here. However, the picture in Asia is more complicated - there's lots of noise around ML China improving sequentially (Louise flagged that China handbag imports turned positive in July for the first time in 18m) but this should be seen in the context of repatriation from Japan and much easier comps. I note that consensus already assumes an improvement in China given the comp base.

Looking at Asia more broadly for a read on total China cluster spending, worth noting that Japan did see some inbound tourist recovery in August. However, Isetan Mitsukoshi told us that duty free sales are still weak here due to a narrowing price gap vs ML China on Luxury Goods. Meanwhile in Macau, GGR was strong in August (+12%) but I would caution that 1) Louise's macro tracker finds only a 0.14 correlation between this data set and regional Luxury sales growth; 2) VIP GGR is still tracking 30- 40% below pre- pandemic levels - it's mass- market GGR that has recovered (to 125- 130%). Overall, I would be surprised if there is a true underlying improvement in China cluster (at home and abroad) spending in Q3.

Putting this all together, I think consensus Q3 numbers look broadly in the right place (better US, slightly worse Asia). I am not arguing for upgrades. However, given bearish positioning, increased confidence that growth and EPS momentum have troughed, should see the Luxury sector rally sustain near- term.

- Next catalysts: 1) We have Pandora and Burberry at our Global Retail Conference in NY tomorrow. Expect Pandora to sound more constructive on current trading than they did at the Q2 stage, citing initial consumer response to the Talisman collection launch (and given we are now past the particularly challenging July comp). For Burberry, while feedback has been data has looked less good for them recently, we assume the message tomorrow will be fairly confident, highlighting success of summer campaign such as Burberry bikini and the festival capsules. More broadly, we expect the event (which includes 70 local US retailers) to confirm an improved discretionary spending backdrop in the US; 2) Milan/Paris Fashion Weeks from 23 Sept with a number of new creatives presenting for the first time (Blazy at Chanel, Anderson at Dior, Demna at Gucci), potentially bringing much needed consumer excitement back to this category; 3) Last week of September – pre-close calls which, based on the above, we think will underpin consensus expectations.

- Spec sales top picks: 1) LVMH – Much easier comp in Japan this quarter, initiatives to drive better traffic coming through and non-leather divisions bottoming out. Consensus +3.5% in Fashion & Leather for next year does not look demanding (on a -5% comp) especially with Anderson likely helping Dior in H2. And strong execution on costs should continue; 2) Moncler – easy comps (remember they were hurt disproportionately by the Olympics last year and late start to A/W), data improving in the US, outerwear category and brand heat still strong in China.
Net Purchase Intent in the US has increased, particularly with higher income cohorts. US retail traffic has also improved despite higher prices
T1M weekly NPI indexed to 1 as of January 1st, 2024, for key income demographic cohorts
Source: HundredX, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Source: LSEG Workspace, Company Data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

India – The government is meeting tomorrow to discuss proposals to lower GST rates. As a reminder, media reports suggested categories with 12% will go down to 5% and those with 28% to 18%. That said, a few articles claim all food products (or potentially all mass consumption FMCG products) will be reduced to 5% GST. We have recently seen a revival in rural spending thanks to 1) a strong winter crop harvest, 2) subdued food inflation, 3) increased welfare spending by several state governments. However, urban

spending has been more mixed. We are hopeful the latter will start to improve from here thanks to 1) income tax cuts, 2) lower interest rates, and now 3) GST reform. Most exposed: Pernod (12% of sales), Unilever (11%), Diageo (9%), Reckitt (6%) and Swatch (6%). Note that alcohol is not taxed at GST level so won't benefit directly from lower rates but we think lower prices elsewhere/higher household available cashflow is a tailwind for spending on these products.
Luxury, Sporting Goods & Brands

Kering - An article in La Lettre argues that 1) the 7bn of Artemis debt disclosed with the Kering nondilutive convert issuance is misrepresentative as it does not include debt at subsidiaries level; 2) interest costs have also increased more than headline figures suggest, with the Kering dividend just covering this; 3) Puma being up for sale proves that Artemis needs cash (note Miss Tweed reported over the weekend that there are not many buyers for this asset). For a reminder of debates in credit markets on Kering, please click here. Note, in mid- August, S&P changed it's outlook on Kering to "negative" and CDS has widened further (+40bps since start of June), now at 125bps. Feedback from equity investors has been that they don't want to fight the "narrative bubble" around new CEO and creative director here. I think, once we hear from both, focus will shift to 2026 numbers with a lot of debate around delivery of consensus double digit EBIT growth recovery.

Armani - Over the weekend, Giorgio Armani told the FT that he is planning for a "gradual transition" of power, saying that he "would like the succession to be organic and not a moment of rupture". This is consistent with prior messaging. As a reminder, Mr Armani previously said that he will leave his company in the hands of close confidantes and that it will be up to them to evaluate strategic options. The press has speculated that these options could include a merger or listing (Bloomberg, FT).

Nestle - The Board has dismissed CEO Laurent Freix with immediate effect following an undisclosed romantic relationship with a direct subordinate. They have appointed Philipp Navratil as his replacement. Mr Navratil has been with the company for 24 years and previously ran a number of coffee units (most recently Nespresso). The statement says there will be no change to the strategic direction of the company but the change at Nestle is somewhat unsettling (second CEO in a year). Incomings this morning asking what does it mean for 2026 margins and potentially the portfolio (as some investors believe the reset wasn't deep enough and that attempts to fix underperforming cells are misplaced i.e. they would prefer disposals). Mr Navratil did present at the recent CMD but is not well known to investors.

China Spirits - Leaf says that, following a Q2 reporting season which saw the baiju names generally missed expectations, Jul- Aug has seen more signs of policy impact normalising. This has been called out by a number of local companies and reflects the gradual fading of effects on private consumption. She still thinks banqueting is being heavily impacted into Mid- Autumn but says this is more relevant for baiju than international premium spirits (or beer).
L'Oreal - GIR remove the stock from the Conviction List, following strong share price performance (+18% since it was added to the list). Olivier remains Buy rated.

Inditex - Feedback suggests investors aren't taking big bets on this name ahead of next week's print. Following Q1 cFX at 4% and the start of Q2 at 6%, many have said that they are waiting to see if the business can get back to 7% in order to buy the name. Richard does forecast 7% for Q2 (implying an acceleration through the quarter) and 6.5% for current trading, but investors feel like visibility is somewhat low.

2- 3 September - Carrefour CEO & CFO in New York and Boston  3- 4 September - GS Global Retail Conference in New York. European companies attending include Adidas, Ahold Delhaize, Burberry, On Holding and Pandora. Deadline for 1x1s is now closed but you can register for presentations here.  16- 17 September - Puig CEO & CFO roadshow in London
22- 24 September – GS German Conference in Munich. Consumer companies attending include adidas, Economy, Delivery Hero, HelloFresh, Henkel, Hugo Boss, Symrise and Zalando. Register HERE
